note:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
amoxicillin / Flagyl / nortriptyline
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
n/v, abd pain, fever
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
ERCP

 
History of Present Illness:
___ year-old with the history below who presented
to ___-M ER yesterday from her nursing home complaining of 
fever,
n/v, and abdominal pain.  She was found to have
choledocholithiasis with cbd stone and sl dilation of the cbd.
CXR was neg for pneumonia.  She was given vancomycin and
ertapenem and transferred to our ED for ERCP.  In our ED she was
found to be hemodymaically stable, stil had some ruq abd pain. 
Noted to have normal lactate (was elevated at BID-M on
presentation).  She was admitted and ERCP team consulted, they 
recommended holding
eliquis today and plan for ercp tomorrow as could then consider
that eliquis has been held long enough for one procedure
(sphincterotomy and stone removal possibly), if clinically 
stable
for same.
 
Past Medical History:
CHF (type unknown), HTN, PAF, GERD,
Hypothyroid, Depression, Fibromyalgia, Lumbar spinal stenosis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Reviewed, found to not be relevant to this illness and 
hospitalization
 
Physical Exam:
VS:  Afebrile and vital signs stable (reviewed in bedside 
record)
General Appearance: pleasant, comfortable, no acute distress
Eyes: PERLL, EOMI, no conjuctival injection, anicteric
ENT: no sinus tenderness, MMM, oropharynx without exudate or
lesions, no supraclavicular or cervical lymphadenopathy, no JVD,
no carotid bruits, no thyromegaly or palpable thyroid nodules
Respiratory: CTA b/l with good air movement throughout
Cardiovascular: RR, S1 and S2 wnl, no murmurs, rubs or gallops
Gastrointestinal: nd, +b/s, soft, ttp ruq, NR, NG, no masses or
HSM
Extremities: no cyanosis, clubbing or edema
Skin: warm, no rashes/no jaundice/no skin ulcerations noted
Neurological: Alert, Cn II-XII intact.  ___ strength throughout. 

No sensory deficits to light touch appreciated.  
2+DTR's-patellar and biceps. No asterixis, no pronator drift,
fluent speech.
Psychiatric: pleasant, appropriate
GU: no catheter in place
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:00AM BLOOD WBC-7.5 RBC-3.78* Hgb-12.0 Hct-36.6 
MCV-97 MCH-31.7 MCHC-32.8 RDW-12.9 RDWSD-45.7 Plt ___
___ 06:55AM BLOOD ___ PTT-33.7 ___
___ 06:53AM BLOOD Glucose-105* UreaN-12 Creat-0.7 Na-143 
K-4.1 Cl-97 HCO3-39* AnGap-11
___ 07:45AM BLOOD ALT-170* AST-43* AlkPhos-120* Amylase-52 
TotBili-0.5
___ 07:45AM BLOOD Lipase-24
___ 06:45AM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01

ERCP:
Impression: Normal major papilla. 
Cannulation of the biliary duct was successful and deep with a 
sphincterotome using a free-hand technique.  
A single 6 mm stone that was causing partial obstruction was 
seen at the lower third of the common bile duct.  
There was post-obstructive dilation to a maximum diameter of 
12mm.  
A sphincterotomy was performed in the 12 o'clock position using 
a sphincterotome over an existing guidewire. 
Balloon sweeps were performed of the common bile duct which 
yielded sludge and a bile pigment stone.  
Further sweeps were performed until no debris was noted.  
Completion occlusion cholangiogram revealed no further filling 
defects.  

 

Recommendations: Return to ward under ongoing care. 
NPO overnight with aggressive IV hydration with LR at 200 cc/hr 

If no abdominal pain in the morning, advance diet to clear 
liquids and then advance as tolerated 
No aspirin, Plavix, NSAIDS, Coumadin for 5 days. 
Continue with antibiotics - Ciprofloxacin 500mg BID x 5 days. 
Follow-up with Dr. ___ as previously scheduled. 
Follow for response and complications. If any abdominal pain, 
fever, jaundice, gastrointestinal bleeding please call ERCP 
fellow on call ___
 
ECHO:
Very suboptimal image quality. The left atrium is normal in 
size. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The 
left ventricular cavity size is normal. Due to suboptimal 
technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be 
fully excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic function 
appears grossly normal (LVEF>55%). The right ventricular free 
wall is hypertrophied. The right ventricular cavity is mildly 
dilated with borderline normal free wall function. The aortic 
valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is 
not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve 
leaflets are mildly thickened. There is mild bileaflet mitral 
valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is 
mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no 
pericardial effusion. There is a large anterior space which most 
likely represents a prominent fat pad although a loculated 
pericqardial effusion cannot be excluded with vertainty. There 
are no echocardiographic signs of tamponade.  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year-old with hx of CHF (type unknown), HTN, PAF on Apixaban 
at baseline, GERD, Hypothyroid, Depression, Fibromyalgia, Lumbar 
spinal stenosis, cataract surgery (chronically keeps rt eye 
closed per son since then) who presented to the BID-M ER from 
her nursing home complaining of fever, n/v, and abdominal pain.  


Diagnoses:
Choledocholithiasis
Acute diastolic CHF
Afib
Depression
GERD
Hypothyroidism

She was found to have choledocholithiasis with cbd stone and sl 
dilation of the cbd.
CXR was neg for pneumonia.  She was given vancomycin and
ertapenem and transferred to our ED for ERCP.  In our ED she was
found to be hemodymaically stable, still had some ruq abd pain. 
Noted to have normal lactate (was elevated at BID-M on
presentation).  She was admitted and ERCP team recommended 
holding
eliquis and plan for ercp the day following as could then 
consider
that eliquis has been held long enough for one procedure
(sphincterotomy and stone removal possibly).  This was done on 
without apparent complication.  Following this,  however 
(following cautious fluids the night after ercp) she developed 
an oxygen requirement and pretty dramatic CXR with effusions, 
pulm edema,  and rales on exam all consistent with an 
exacerbation of heart failure.  Aggressively diuresed 
subsequently over days with Lasix 20mg IV BID.   On 
ciprofloxacin po following ERCP for biliary 
infection/cholangitis and she completed a course.

Ultimately her lung exam and symptoms improved with IV diuresis. 
 She was negative LOS about 3L.  Echo performed showed preserved 
heart function as above.  She was continued on her metoprolol 
and lisinopril.  She was transitioned to her Lasix 20mg daily.  
She was able to be weaned off oxygen, she was 90-93% on RA on 
discharge though still taking oxygen for comfort.  You can use 
1L 02 as needed for comfort.  Part of her symptoms may also be 
due to poor inspiratory effort as deep breathing exercises 
improved her oxygenation.  Would continue to encourage deep 
breathing.

Her apixaban and other home medications were continued.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires 
futher investigation.
1. Levothyroxine Sodium 75 mcg PO DAILY 
2. DULoxetine 80 mg PO DAILY 
3. Venlafaxine XR 150 mg PO QAM 
4. Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY 
5. Diltiazem Extended-Release 180 mg PO DAILY 
6. Potassium Chloride 20 mEq PO DAILY 
7. QUEtiapine Fumarate 12.5 mg PO QAM 
8. Gabapentin 200 mg PO BID 
9. Metoprolol Tartrate 50 mg PO BID 
10. ClonazePAM 0.5 mg PO BID 
11. Ranitidine 150 mg PO BID 
12. Apixaban 5 mg PO BID 
13. Venlafaxine XR 37.5 mg PO QPM 
14. TraZODone 50 mg PO QHS 
15. Gabapentin 300 mg PO QHS 
16. QUEtiapine Fumarate 25 mg PO QHS 
17. Ipratropium-Albuterol Neb 1 NEB NEB Q6H:PRN wheezing 
18. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Apixaban 5 mg PO BID 
2. ClonazePAM 0.5 mg PO BID 
3. DULoxetine 80 mg PO DAILY 
4. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 
5. Gabapentin 200 mg PO BID 
6. Gabapentin 300 mg PO QHS 
7. Ipratropium-Albuterol Neb 1 NEB NEB Q6H:PRN wheezing 
8. Levothyroxine Sodium 75 mcg PO DAILY 
9. Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY 
10. Metoprolol Tartrate 50 mg PO BID 
11. QUEtiapine Fumarate 12.5 mg PO QAM 
12. QUEtiapine Fumarate 25 mg PO QHS 
13. Ranitidine 150 mg PO BID 
14. TraZODone 50 mg PO QHS 
15. Venlafaxine XR 150 mg PO QAM 
16. Venlafaxine XR 37.5 mg PO QPM 
17. Diltiazem Extended-Release 180 mg PO DAILY 
18. Potassium Chloride 20 mEq PO DAILY 
Hold for K > 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Choledocholithiasis
Acute diastolic CHF
Atrial fibrillation
GERD
Depression

 
Discharge Condition:
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Patient was admitted with abdominal pain due to stone in the 
bile duct.  She underwent successful stone removal and has 
completed a course of antibiotics.  her course was complicated 
by heart failure requiring IV Lasix.  She has since improved and 
requires ___ liter of oxygen.  She has been started on low dose 
Lasix in addition to her chronic medications
 
Followup Instructions:
___

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
